across.text: Very bad – being sanctioned, losing head
across.explanation: AWFUL(i.e. “very bad”). Solution is LAWFUL (i.e. “sanctioned”) with the first letter removed (i.e. “losing head”).

across.text: Caught in withdrawal with English soldiers – time for agitation
across.explanation: EXCITEMENT(i.e. “agitation”). Solution is C (a recognised abbreviation of “caught” used in cricket) placed “in” EXIT (i.e. “withdrawal”) and then followed by E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”), MEN (i.e. “soldiers”) and T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”), like so: EX(C)IT-E-MEN-T.

across.text: Think about new name for herb
across.explanation: FENNEL(i.e. “herb”). Solution is FEEL (i.e. “think”) placed “about” N and N (both recognised abbreviations of “new” and “name”), like so: FE(N-N)EL.

across.text: Only crag around that’s home to fine raptor
across.explanation: GYRFALCON, a bird of prey (i.e. “raptor”). Did a Google Image search – oooh, pretty. Solution is F (a recognised abbreviation of “fine” used when grading pencils) placed in an anagram (indicated by “around”) of ONLY CRAG, like so: GYR(F)ALCON.

across.text: Remarkably ungodly Titans must be destroyed
across.explanation: OUTSTANDINGLY(i.e. “remarkably”). “Must be destroyed” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of UNGODLY TITANS. This took me longer than it should as I couldn’t look past “astoundingly” even though I knew it didn’t have enough Ts. Stoopid brain.

across.text: Press function that’s very crowded
across.explanation: SQUEEZE.Okay, here’s the first solution I’m not 100% sure about, so watch out. I’m going for “squeeze” being another word for “press”, but the rest of the clue has me flummoxed. Moving on with my life…

across.text: Tangle of limbs – frogs slip, now shedding skins
across.explanation: IMBROGLIO(i.e. “tangle”). “Shedding skins” suggests we remove the first and last letters of the wordsLIMBS,FROGS,SLIPandNOW.

across.text: Woodworker hasn’t to criticise log
across.explanation: ENTER(i.e. to “log”). Solution is CARPENTER (i.e. “woodworker”) with CARP removed (i.e. “hasn’t to criticise”).

across.text: Influence of Austen novel not working? See “Sense” rewritten
across.explanation: PERSUASIVENESS(i.e. “influence”). A bit of a stinker this. Solution is PERSUASION (i.e. “Austen novel”) with ON removed (i.e. “not working”), then followed by V (i.e. “see” – V is a recognised abbreviation of “vide”, which is Latin for “see”… I know, I know…) and an anagram (indicated by “rewritten”) of SENSE, like so: PERSUASI-V-ENESS. Sheesh!

across.text: Spotted millions too much under control
across.explanation: MOTTLED(i.e. “spotted”). Solution is M (a recognised abbreviation of “millions”) followed by OTT (i.e. “too much”, or Over The Top – which, coincidentally, was the first film I saw at the cinema. Don’t judge me; we had the choice of either that or Mannequin) and LED (i.e. “under control”).

across.text: Make new assessment concerning girl dead after eating uranium
across.explanation: RE-EVALUATE(i.e. “make new assessment”). Solution is RE (i.e. “concerning”) followed by VAL (i.e. “girl”) and LATE (i.e. “dead”) wrapped around, or “eating”, U (chemical symbol of “uranium”) like so: RE-EVA-L(U)ATE.

across.text: After stone’s removed, red guy perhaps is infectious
across.explanation: COMMUNICABLE(i.e. “infectious”). Solution is COMMUNIST (i.e. “red”) with ST removed (i.e. “after stone’s removed”) and then followed by CABLE (i.e. a “guy”), like so: COMMUNI-CABLE.

across.text: Importance of manservant being reduced outside upper class
across.explanation: VALUE(i.e. “importance”). Solution is VALET (i.e. “manservant”) with the final letter removed (i.e. “reduced”) and remainder placed around U (a recognised abbreviation used to denote the “upper class”), like so: VAL(U)E.

across.text: Wizard’s more angry about church resistance
across.explanation: SORCERER(i.e. “wizard”). Solution is SORER (i.e. “more angry”) placed “about” CE (i.e. “church”, specifically the Church of England) and R (a recognised abbreviation for electrical “resistance”), like so: SOR(CE-R)ER.

across.text: Battle’s appeal perhaps is a test of strength
across.explanation: TUG-OF-WAR. Solution satisfies both “battle’s appeal” and “test of strength”.

across.text: Generosity of Ayrshire town about English home Counties
across.explanation: LARGESSE(i.e. “generosity”). Solution is LARGS (i.e. “Ayrshire town” – not one I’m familiar with, if I’m honest) placed “about” E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) and followed by SE (i.e. “home Counties”, or, generally, the South East), like so: LARG(E)SSE.

across.text: Keeping French company in hand with a big Spanish house
across.explanation: HACIENDA(i.e. “big Spanish house”). Solution is CIE (i.e. “French company” – while we abbreviate “company” to “co.”, the French abbreviate “compagnie” to “cie”, so now you know) being “kept” in HAND and then followed by A, like so: HA(CIE)ND-A.

across.text: Show contempt for society and banal sentimentality
across.explanation: SCORN(i.e. “show contempt”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “society”) followed by CORN (i.e. “banal sentimentality”).

across.text: Magnanimous in one’s real nature, beset by selfish desire
across.explanation: GREAT-HEARTED(i.e. “magnanimous”). Solution is AT HEART (i.e. “one’s real nature”) “beset by” GREED (i.e. “selfish desire”), like so: GRE(AT HEART)ED.

across.text: Energy in river gets less after its start, characteristic of the plain
across.explanation: SEVERENESS(i.e. “characteristic of the plain”). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “energy”) placed “in” SEVERN (i.e. “river”) and followed by ESS (i.e. “less after it’s start”, i.e. the letters following the initial letter of the word “less”), like so: SEVER(E)N-ESS.

across.text: Former role in Goethe, hard for female to get everything out of
across.explanation: EXHAUST(i.e. “to get everything out of”). Solution is EX (i.e. “former”) followed by HAUST (i.e. “role in Goethe, hard for female”, i.e. “Faust” with F replaced by H, both being recognised abbreviations of “female” and “hard” respectively).

across.text: Making up earlier public relations lie about ecstasy
across.explanation: PREFABRICATION(i.e. “making up earlier”). Solution is PR (short for “public relations”) and FABRICATION (i.e. “lie”) placed “about” E (being a recognised abbreviation of “ecstasy”), like so: PR-(E)-FABRICATION.

across.text: Husband’s in French resort area with specialised group
across.explanation: NICHE(i.e. “specialised group”). Solution is H (a recognised abbreviation of “husband”) placed “in” NICE (i.e. “French resort”), like so: NIC(H)E.

across.text: Horseman heard to pine from day to day?
across.explanation: NIGHTLONG. Solution satisfies both “horseman heard” – suggesting a homophone of “knight” – “to pine” i.e. long, and “from” i.e. between “day to day”. A curious omission from my Chambers, this one.

across.text: Some wire electrician put in again
across.explanation: RE-ELECT(i.e. “put in again”). “Some” suggests the solution is hidden within the clue, like so: WI(RE ELECT)RICIAN.

across.text: Elegant literature allowed in ghastly best seller?
across.explanation: BELLES LETTRES(i.e. “elegant literature” – probably not something you’d find on my bookshelves). Solution is LET (i.e. “allowed”) placed “in” an anagram (indicated by “ghastly”) of “best seller”, like so: BELLES (LET)TRES.

across.text: It went with the need to recompose at the end of a score
across.explanation: TWENTIETH(i.e. “at the end of a score”). “Recompose” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of IT WENT and THE.

across.text: Youthful bachelor, rather bashful, avoiding clubs
across.explanation: BOYISH(i.e. “youthful”). Solution is B (a recognised abbreviation of “bachelor”) followed by OYISH (i.e. “rather bashful, avoiding clubs”, i.e. the word “coyish” with the letter C (a recognised abbreviation of “clubs” used in card games) removed), like so: B-OYISH.

across.text: Barbican may defend this sketch by English composer
across.explanation: DRAWBRIDGE(i.e. “Barbican may defend this” – a barbican is a fortified outpost). Solution is DRAW (i.e. “sketch”) followed by Frank BRIDGE (i.e. “English composer”).

across.text: One who travels up Amazon, say, but velocity’s small
across.explanation: RISER(i.e. “one who travels up”). Solution is RIVER (i.e. “Amazon, say”) with V (a recognised abbreviation of “velocity”) replaced by S (ditto “small”).

down.text: Gold rush in the air for part of the summer
down.explanation: AUGUST(i.e. “part of the summer”). Solution is AU (chemical symbol of “gold”) followed by GUST (i.e. “rush in the air”).

down.text: Bank employee follows mint guide to future developments
down.explanation: FORTUNE TELLER(i.e. “guide to future developments”). Solution is TELLER (i.e. “bank employee”) “following” FORTUNE (i.e. “mint”).

down.text: Pull out a lot of pages
down.explanation: LEAVE.And here’s the next solution I’m not 100% on, so, again, be careful here. I’m going for “leave” being another word for “pull out”, but, frankly the setter has left me stone cold after that.

down.text: Excellent rate when moving waste
down.explanation: EXCRETA(i.e. “waste”). Solution is EXC (a recognised abbreviation of “excellent”) followed by an anagram (indicated by “when moving”) of RATE, like so: EXC-RETA.

down.text: Shout about arranged coalition bringing parties together
down.explanation: CONCILIATORY(i.e. “bringing parties together”). Solution is CRY (i.e. “shout”) placed “about” an anagram (indicated by “arranged”) of COALITION, like so: C(ONCILIATO)RY.

down.text: Worried nearly all fish escaped into surrounding area
down.explanation: TROUBLED(i.e. “worried”). Solution is TROUT with the final letter removed (i.e. “nearly all fish”) followed by BLED (i.e. “escape into surrounding area”).

down.text: Sailor losing pounds eating unknown biscuit
down.explanation: MATZO, a Jewish unleavened flatbread eaten during Passover (i.e. “biscuit” – albeit veeeeery loosely). Solution is MATLO (a slang word for “sailor” I wasn’t familiar with) with L removed (i.e. “losing pounds”, L being a recognised abbreviation of “pounds”) and the remainder “eating” Z (i.e. “unknown” – setters love using this to represent the letters X, Y or Z), like so: MAT(Z)O.

down.text: Ordering of ten omelets is annoying
down.explanation: NETTLESOME(i.e. “annoying” – a bit like some of the clues in this puzzle). “Ordering of” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TEN OMELETS.

down.text: Demanding information during flight?
down.explanation: EXIGENT(i.e. urgent, pressing, or “demanding”). Solution is GEN (i.e. “information”) placed “during” EXIT (i.e. “flight”) like so: EXI(GEN)T. Nice word. I suspect I’ll see it several times over the coming weeks.

down.text: Almost one hundred and fifty in boat’s cabaret
down.explanation: NIGHTCLUB(i.e. “cabaret”). Solution is NIGH (i.e. “almost”) followed by TUB (i.e. “boat”) wrapped around CL (Roman numerals for “one hundred and fifty”), like so: NIGH-T(CL)UB.

down.text: Killer beheaded hen
down.explanation: LAYER(i.e. “hen”). Solution is SLAYER (i.e. “killer”) with its first letter removed (i.e. “beheaded”).

down.text: Insane commuter upset out of all proportion
down.explanation: INCOMMENSURATE(i.e. “out of all proportion”). “Upset” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of INSANE COMMUTER.

down.text: Announcement broadcast about gallery being given millions
down.explanation: STATEMENT(i.e. “announcement”). Solution is SENT (i.e. “broadcast”) placed “about” TATE (i.e. “gallery”) and M (a recognised abbreviation of “millions”), like so: S(TATE-M)ENT.

down.text: Note: habitual drunkard chap is known to a few
down.explanation: ESOTERIC(i.e. “known [only] to a few”). Solution is E (i.e. a musical “note”) followed by SOT (i.e. “habitual drunkard”) and ERIC (i.e. “chap”).

down.text: Eats last of meals outside back in gloom
down.explanation: DREARINESS(i.e. “gloom”). Solution is DINES (i.e. “eats”) and S (i.e. “last of meals”, i.e. the last letter of the word “meals”) placed “outside” of REAR (i.e. “back”), like so: D(REAR)INES-S.

down.text: Composer with work mounted in Tuesday’s programme
down.explanation: TRAVELOGUE(i.e. “programme”). Solution is RAVEL (i.e. “composer” – him what done “Bolero”, like) and OG (i.e. “work mounted”, i.e. the word “go” reversed) all placed in TUE (short for “Tuesday”), like so: T(RAVEL-OG)UE.

down.text: Naively unsure, but not about small muscle smarting
down.explanation: UNSUSPECTINGLY(i.e. “naively unsure”). Solution is UNSURE with RE removed (i.e. “but not about”, RE being often used to denote “about” or “regarding”), followed by S (a recognised abbreviation of “small”), PEC (i.e. “muscle”) and TINGLY (i.e. “smarting”), like so: UNSU-S-PEC-TINGLY.

down.text: What will support some fliers showing signs of ageing
down.explanation: CROWS FEET. Solution satisfies both “what will support some fliers” and “signs of ageing”.

down.text: Everyone initially pursuing beer in pins in contract wording?
down.explanation: LEGALESE(i.e. “contract wording”). Solution is LEGS (i.e. “pins”) placed around ALE (i.e. “beer”) and followed by E (i.e. “everyone initially”, i.e. the first letter of the word “everyone”), like so: LEG(ALE)S-E.

down.text: Unity keeps a number in good condition
down.explanation: WHOLESOMENESS(i.e. “in good condition”). Solution is WHOLENESS (i.e. “unity”) “keeping” SOME (i.e. “a number”) like so: WHOLE(SOME)NESS.

down.text: Teenage drugs circulating in one group
down.explanation: UNSEGREGATED(i.e. “in one group”). “Circulating” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TEENAGE DRUGS.

down.text: Hold up a reptile – one giving birth?
down.explanation: PROPAGATOR(i.e. “one giving birth”). Solution is PROP (i.e. “hold up”) followed by A GATOR (i.e. “a reptile”).

down.text: Properly European count seen around this in Rome?
down.explanation: ETHICALLY(i.e. “properly”). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “European”) followed by TALLY (i.e. “count”) wrapped “around” HIC (i.e. “this in Rome” – the Latin for “this” is “hic”), like so: E-T(HIC)ALLY.

down.text: Driver having to go round old noisy drinker
down.explanation: CAROUSER(i.e. “noisy drinker”). Solution is CAR USER (i.e. “driver”) placed “round” O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”), like so: CAR-(O)-USER.

down.text: Having no home, the first two thrown out will be idle
down.explanation: USELESS(i.e. “idle”). Solution is HOUSELESS (i.e. “having no home”) with the “first two [letters] thrown out”.

down.text: Obtain returns in main train
down.explanation: CORTEGE(i.e. “train”). Solution is GET (i.e. “obtains”) reversed (i.e. “returns”) and placed “in” CORE (i.e. “main”), like so: COR(TEG)E.

down.text: And expensive in Paris for one who’s eating out
down.explanation: ETCHER(i.e. “one who’s eating out” material with acid). Solution is ET CHER (i.e. “and expensive in Paris”, i.e. the French for “and” and “dear”).

down.text: Nick? He died an important person
down.explanation: NABOB(i.e. “an important person”). Solution is NAB (i.e. “nick”) followed by OB (a recognised abbreviation of the Latin word “obiter”, meaning “died”).

down.text: Cast line after tench, missing those in the middle
down.explanation: THROW(i.e. “cast”). Solution is ROW (i.e. “line”) placed “after” TH (i.e. “tench, missing those in the middle”, i.e. the word “tench” with the middle letters removed), like so: TH-ROW.

down.text: County town demolishing church compound
down.explanation: ESTER(i.e. “compound”). Solution is CHESTER (i.e. “county town”) with CH removed (i.e. “demolishing church”, CH being a recognised abbreviation of “church”).
